title: Von der Leyen sets up crash pad in Commission HQ
text:
Ursula von der Leyen is setting up her own pied-à-tierre inside the Commission's Brussels headquarters | Kenzo Triboullard/AFP via Getty Images Von der Leyen sets up crash pad in Commission HQ Work is already under way on her new private quarters, measuring 25 square meters.

European Commission President-elect Ursula von der Leyen is setting up her own pied-à-tierre inside the Commission's Brussels headquarters, Welt newspaper reported, citing unnamed EU sources.

The German conservative politician takes up the post on November 1, but work is already under way on her new private quarters, measuring a cosy 25 square meters, just a few steps away from her office on the 13th floor of the Berlaymont building, Welt reported.

This would be similar to von der Leyen's sleeping arrangements in her last job as Germany's defense minister: She had a tiny bedroom inside the ministry for her use during the week and spent the weekends with her husband and seven children at the family home near Hannover.

The post of Commission president does not come with an official residence. The outgoing President Jean-Claude Juncker griped in the media about the cramped conditions in the hotel apartment rented for him for €3,250 a month. “I can’t talk to official visitors sitting on my bed,” he told Bild in an interview.

Juncker complained that he didn't enjoy the same accommodation perks as ambassadors in Brussels but said NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg sometimes invited him over for an evening at his official "Schloss."

Welt said von der Leyen's decision to overnight inside the Berlaymont would reduce the need for external security, since the Commission headquarters already has round-the-clock guards.
